docs.lead_paragraph: Not so long ago, pregnant women were almost universally warned to avoid strenuous activity. Running, cycling, skiing, horseback riding, singles tennis -- all were off limits. Only walking had widespread approval, and even that was to be limited to about a mile a day, preferably broken up into several short sessions. But faced with women's growing interest in exercise and sports and their desire to stay in shape while a new life takes shape within them, doctors gave exercise during pregnancy a second look. And to the surprise of many, medical research has shown that most women can safely continue to exercise throughout pregnancy, as long as they make some sensible adjustments to their routines. And for those women who were relatively inactive before conceiving and now wish to get in better shape before baby comes, it is even safe to begin exercise programs during pregnancy.

headline.main: Simple Adjustments for a Fit Pregnancy

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: An important medication not mentioned in the Personal Health column ''Drugs, Safe and Not Safe, in Pregnancy'' (Nov. 9) is methadone, which has been shown in many studies over the last 30 years to be safe and effective during pregnancy. Breast-feeding poses no problem and is recommended. Babies born to methadone-maintained women often have physical dependence and a withdrawal syndrome that is easily treated with phenobarbital and paregoric.

docs.lead_paragraph: There may be little common ground in the long-running debate over sex education, but people on all sides agree on this much: Until quite recently, teenage girls had little access to information about their bodies and their sexuality. In 1912, Margaret H. Sanger wrote a series of articles called What Every Girl Should Know for a radical newspaper, The Call. The articles later became a short book, dedicated to working girls of the world which described sexual anatomy, conception and birth, and even masturbation. But, said Judith E. Steinhart, the senior educator at Columbia University's health education program, few working girls ever got a chance to read it: postal officials confiscated it on grounds of obscenity.
